ingredients: Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
Freshly grated Parmesan or pecorino cheese, for serving
instructions: In a food processor, combine the carrots, celery, onion, garlic, and fennel seeds. Process until the veggies are broken down into small pieces, about 1 minute. In a large Dutch oven, heat the olive oil over medium-high heat. When the oil is shimmering, add the carrot mixture and season generously with salt, black pepper, and pepper flakes. Cook, stirring occasionally, until softened, 8 to 10 minutes. Add the mushrooms to the food processor and pulse about 6 times to break them down. Add the mushrooms to the pot along with the cumin, paprika, and a pinch of salt. Cook until the mushrooms have released their liquid, about 5 minutes. Add the wine and simmer until almost completely evaporated, about 10 minutes. Add the tomato paste and bay leaves. Cook until fragrant, about 2 minutes. Add the milk and broth. Simmer for 20-30 minutes. Cook the tagliatelle according to package directions. Serve the sauce over pasta with grated cheese.
author: DAN PELOSI

name: Chicken Marsala
ingredients: 1 1/2 pounds boneless, skinless chicken breasts, pounded thin
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
instructions: Pat the chicken dry with paper towels and season on both sides with salt and pepper. Place the flour in a shallow bowl and dredge half of the chicken in the flour, shaking off any excess. In a large skillet, heat 2 tablespoons of the olive oil over medium heat. When the oil is shimmering, arrange the dredged chicken in the skillet and fry until the flour is golden brown, about 4 minutes per side. Transfer to a platter. Dredge the remaining chicken, heat 1 more tablespoon of oil in the skillet, and fry. Transfer to the platter. If the skillet is dry, add another tablespoon of olive oil. Add the shallot and cook, scraping up the browned bits, until softened, about 2 minutes. Add the mushrooms and cook until golden brown, about 4 minutes. Season with salt and pepper. Pour in the Marsala and chicken broth. Simmer until reduced by half, about 3 minutes. Remove from heat and add the butter. Stir as the butter melts to create a smooth, creamy sauce. Pour the sauce over the chicken, garnish with parsley, and serve.
author: DAN PELOSI

name: Olive Oil Ice Cream
instructions: In a stand mixer fitted with the whisk attachment (or a large bowl if using a handheld mixer), combine the cream, salt, and vanilla. Beginning on low speed and increasing to medium, whisk until stiff peaks form, 3 to 4 minutes. Remove the bowl from the stand mixer. Add the condensed milk and olive oil. Use a rubber spatula to fold everything together, scraping along the sides and the bottom of the bowl, making sure the mixture stays light and fluffy. Pour the mixture into a 9x13-inch baking dish, cover tightly with cling wrap, and freeze for at least 8 hours, until the ice cream is fully set. Remove from the freezer to soften about 5 minutes before serving. Store tightly covered in the freezer for up to 1 month.
author: DAN PELOSI

name: Sheet Pan Blackened Salmon with Potatoes and Creamy Cilantro Sauce
ingredients: For sauce: 1/2 cup whole-milk Greek yogurt
Grated zest and juice of 1 lime
For blackened seasoning: 2 teaspoons light brown sugar
1 1/2 pounds salmon, skinned and cut into 1-inch cubes
4 red potatoes (about 8 ounces), cut into 1/2-inch chunks
instructions: Preheat the oven to 400°F. Blend yogurt, olive oil, lime zest and juice, cilantro, garlic, and salt until smooth. Refrigerate. Mix together brown sugar, paprika, garlic powder, salt, cumin, oregano, pepper, and chile flakes. Toss salmon with 2 tablespoons oil and coat with spice mix. Place potatoes on sheet pan with 2 tablespoons oil, salt and pepper. Bake for 6 minutes. Add broccoli with remaining oil and seasoning. Add salmon to pan. Bake until salmon is opaque, 8 to 10 minutes. Serve with cilantro lime sauce and lemon slices.
author: BROCC YOUR BODY

name: Spicy Beef Rice Bowls
ingredients: For sauce: 1/4 cup reduced-sodium soy sauce
2 tablespoons Thai sweet chili sauce or sriracha
1/4 teaspoon chili powder or cayenne pepper
instructions: Make the sauce: Whisk together soy sauce, honey, vinegar, sesame oil, and chili sauce. Set aside. Heat avocado oil in a large skillet over medium heat. Add green onions, ginger, and garlic and cook until fragrant, 1 to 2 minutes. Increase heat to medium-high, add beef, salt, and chili powder. Break up meat and let cook undisturbed for 1 to 2 minutes to brown. Flip and cook 30 seconds more. Add sauce and simmer until most liquid is absorbed, about 5 minutes. Serve over rice with cucumber, green onion, and sesame seeds.
author: BROCC YOUR BODY

name: One-Pot Chicken Pasta
ingredients: 2 boneless, skinless chicken breasts (about 1 1/2 pounds), cut into bite-size pieces
1/2 cup oil-packed sun-dried tomatoes, thinly sliced
instructions: Season chicken with Italian seasoning, garlic powder, salt, and pepper. Heat 2 tablespoons olive oil in a Dutch oven over medium-high heat. Cook chicken until no longer pink, about 4 minutes. Set aside. Add remaining oil, reduce heat to medium. Cook onion and garlic until translucent, 5 to 7 minutes. Add sun-dried tomatoes, chicken broth, and half-and-half. Bring to a boil. Reduce heat, add pasta, cover and simmer until al dente, 13 to 15 minutes. Stir in chicken, spinach, and Parmesan. Serve with parsley.
author: BROCC YOUR BODY

name: Chicken Satay and Kale Salad
ingredients: 1 1/2 pounds boneless, skinless chicken breasts or thighs, cut into bite-size pieces
1 bunch curly kale, stems removed, leaves chopped (about 4 cups)
2 teaspoons fresh ginger, peeled and grated
instructions:
Make the dressing: In a food processor or blender, combine olive oil, peanut butter, soy sauce, honey, sesame oil, vinegar, lime juice, ginger, and garlic. Pulse until smooth, 1 to 2 minutes. Set aside.

Marinate chicken: Combine chicken, soy sauce, sesame oil, ginger, sriracha, turmeric, and pepper. Refrigerate 30 minutes or overnight. Preheat oven to 425°F. Thread chicken on skewers and place on lined sheet pan. Bake until cooked through, 15 to 20 minutes. Combine kale, bell pepper, cucumber, peanuts, green onion, and mint. Toss with peanut ginger dressing. Serve salad topped with chicken skewers.
author: BROCC YOUR BODY

name: Pistachio Pesto Salmon
instructions: Preheat oven to 400°F. Line a sheet pan with foil. In a food processor, combine pistachios, basil, Parmesan, garlic, salt, pepper, lemon juice, and 2 tablespoons olive oil. Pulse 3 to 4 times. While running, slowly drizzle in remaining oil. Transfer to bowl and add more oil if needed until spreadable. Set salmon on sheet pan and generously coat top with pesto. Bake until opaque in center, 10 to 12 minutes. Serve with lemon wedges.
author: BROCC YOUR BODY

name: Coconut Green Curry Shrimp
ingredients: 1 1/2 pounds large shrimp, peeled and deveined
Grated zest and juice of 1 lime
1 cup fresh basil leaves, thinly sliced
instructions: Heat 1 tablespoon coconut oil in a Dutch oven over medium heat. Add shrimp, season with salt and pepper, and cook about 2 minutes per side. Set aside. Add remaining coconut oil, onion, bell pepper, jalapeno, ginger, and garlic. Cook until onion is translucent, 6 to 8 minutes. Add curry paste and stir. Add fish sauce, soy sauce, brown sugar, and coconut milk. Bring to a simmer. Return shrimp to pan and stir in lime zest, juice, and basil. Serve over rice garnished with cilantro.
author: BROCC YOUR BODY

name: Banana Cake with Dark Chocolate Frosting & Sea Salt
ingredients: 2 cups mashed ripe bananas (about 4 large bananas)
1 cup (200 grams) lightly packed light brown sugar
3/4 cup (155 grams) unrefined coconut oil, melted, or vegetable oil
1 cup (240 grams) sour cream, at room temperature
9 ounces (255 grams) dark chocolate (70 to 85% cacao), broken into pieces
1/3 cup (80 grams) heavy cream, at room temperature
2 sticks (8 ounces/226 grams) unsalted butter, at room temperature
instructions: Preheat oven to 350°F. Grease a 9x13-inch cake pan with cooking spray and line bottom with parchment paper. In a large bowl, combine banana, granulated sugar, brown sugar, eggs, coconut oil, sour cream, and vanilla and whisk until smooth. In a separate bowl, whisk together flour, baking soda, salt, and cinnamon. Pour dry ingredients into wet and mix until combined. Pour into pan and bake until a tester comes out clean, 35 to 40 minutes. Let cool 30 minutes in pan, then invert onto board, remove parchment, and invert onto serving platter. For frosting: Melt chocolate in a heatproof bowl over simmering water. Set aside to cool completely. Combine heavy cream and espresso powder. In a stand mixer, beat butter until fluffy, 2 to 3 minutes. Add confectioners' sugar and beat until smooth. Gradually add cream mixture. Gradually add cooled chocolate and mix until smooth. Spread frosting over cooled cake and sprinkle with sea salt.
author: LIDEY HEUCK

name: Blueberry Muffin Sugar Cookies
ingredients: 2 sticks (8 ounces/226 grams) unsalted butter, at room temperature
2 ounces (57 grams) cream cheese, at room temperature
3/4 cup (150 grams) granulated sugar, plus more for sprinkling
1/4 cup (100 grams) lightly packed light brown sugar
1 cup (150 grams) blueberries, rinsed and patted dry
instructions: Preheat oven to 350°F and line two sheet pans with parchment paper. In a medium bowl, whisk together flour, cornstarch, baking powder, salt, and cinnamon. In a stand mixer fitted with paddle attachment, beat butter, cream cheese, granulated sugar, and brown sugar on medium-high speed until light and fluffy, about 3 minutes. Add egg and vanilla and mix until combined. With mixer on low, add dry ingredients and mix until just combined. Gently fold in blueberries by hand. Scoop 3-tablespoon balls of dough onto prepared pans, spacing them apart. Bake one pan at a time until cookies are just starting to brown at edges but still soft, 20 to 22 minutes. Cool 10 minutes on pan, then transfer to wire rack. Store in sealed container at room temperature for up to 3 days.
author: LIDEY HEUCK

name: Chicken Stir-Fry with Green Beans and Bell Pepper
author: HOT SHEET COOKBOOK
ingredients: One 1-inch piece fresh ginger, finely grated
1 1/2 pounds boneless, skinless chicken thighs, cut into 1-inch pieces
1 small yellow onion, halved and thinly sliced
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
instructions: Position racks in lower and upper thirds of oven and preheat to 425°F. Whisk together soy sauce, sesame oil, sugar, vinegar, garlic, and ginger. Add chicken and mix well. Set aside. On a sheet pan, toss green beans, onion, bell pepper, and oil. Season with salt and pepper. Roast on lower rack for about 10 minutes until starting to soften. Sprinkle cornstarch over chicken and stir. Remove sheet from oven, stir vegetables, and place chicken over vegetables in single layer. Drizzle any remaining marinade over everything. Return to oven and roast for about 10 minutes until chicken is cooked through. Turn on broiler and move to upper rack. Broil 2 to 5 minutes until browned in spots. Top with scallion and serve with rice.

name: Gochujang Steak Fajitas with Kimchi, Onions, and Peppers
author: HOT SHEET COOKBOOK
ingredients: 1 tablespoon dark brown sugar or honey
1/2 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper, divided
1 pound skirt or flank steak, thinly sliced across the grain
3 large bell peppers (mix of colors), sliced
1 large red onion, halved and sliced
instructions: Position racks in lower and upper thirds of oven. Turn on broiler. Place a sheet pan on top rack. Combine gochujang, 1 tablespoon oil, brown sugar, 1 teaspoon salt, coriander, cumin, and 1/4 teaspoon pepper. Add steak and toss to coat. Set aside. Cut bell peppers and onion into 1/4-inch slices. Toss with remaining 2 tablespoons oil and remaining salt and pepper. Remove hot sheet from oven. Spread vegetables in single layer. Broil 5 to 8 minutes until starting to brown. Push vegetables to one side, arrange steak on other side. Wrap tortillas in foil. Return sheet pan to top rack, place tortillas on lower rack. Broil about 5 minutes until steak is browned and cooked through. Serve with warmed tortillas, kimchi, sour cream, lime wedges, and hot sauce.

name: Japanese Oven Burgers with Cabbage Salad
author: HOT SHEET COOKBOOK
ingredients: 1 small yellow onion, very finely chopped
instructions: Position rack in middle of oven, set a sheet pan on it, and preheat to 425°F. Combine beef, pork, onion, panko, milk, egg, salt, mustard, nutmeg, and pepper. Mix gently until combined. Refrigerate 15 minutes. Divide into 10 portions and shape into balls. Remove hot sheet from oven, add oil and tilt to distribute. Place patties on pan, spacing 1 inch apart. Press thumb into center of each. Roast 10 minutes until edges sizzle. Flip and roast 6 to 8 minutes more until cooked through (160°F). For sauce: combine ketchup, mustard, Worcestershire, soy sauce, brown sugar, and butter on the hot sheet pan and stir until butter melts. For salad: whisk vinegar, soy sauce, and mustard, then whisk in oil. Toss with cabbage. Serve burgers with sauce, cabbage salad, and rice.

name: Oven Fish Tacos with Avocado, Radishes, and Cumin-Lime Crema
author: HOT SHEET COOKBOOK
ingredients: 1 pound flaky fish fillets (tilapia, cod, or haddock)
instructions: Preheat oven to 425°F. Lightly grease a sheet pan. Pat fish dry. Mix salt, cumin, chili powder, chipotle powder, and black pepper. Rub spice mixture over fillets and place on pan. Roast 12 to 14 minutes until fish flakes with a fork. For guacamole: mash avocados lightly, add tomato, onion, cilantro, jalapeno, salt, pepper, and lime juice. For crema: mix sour cream, lime zest, cumin, lime juice, and salt. Serve fish in warm tortillas with guacamole, crema, and sliced radishes.

name: Slab Bee Sting Pizza
author: HOT SHEET COOKBOOK
instructions: Make dough: In stand mixer with dough hook, stir water and yeast; let sit 5 minutes. Stir in 2 tablespoons oil and salt. Add flour in two batches, mix on low until incorporated. Increase to medium-low and mix until smooth and slightly tacky, about 3 minutes. Grease a bowl with remaining oil, transfer dough, turn to coat, cover and refrigerate 24 to 48 hours. To bake: Preheat oven to 500°F. Oil two quarter-sheet pans. Divide dough in half, stretch to fit pans. Let rise 30 minutes. For sauce: mix crushed tomatoes, oil, and pepper flakes. Top dough with mozzarella first, then dollop sauce over cheese (grandma-style). Add soppressata and onion. Bake 15 to 20 minutes until crust is golden and cheese is bubbling. Drizzle with hot honey before serving.

name: Oven Quesadillas
author: ALI SLAGLE
instructions:
Heat the oven to 450°F and stick a sheet pan in there. Coarsely grate 1 cup sharp Cheddar cheese (about 4 ounces) into a medium bowl. Drain and rinse 1 (15-ounce) can black beans and add to the bowl. Add 1 teaspoon dried oregano, season to taste with salt and pepper, and stir to combine.

Lightly grease the heated sheet pan with neutral oil. Put 4 (6-inch) flour tortillas on the baking sheet. Spoon a heaping ½ cup of the bean-cheese mix on top of each tortilla, spread it out, then top with another tortilla. Lightly oil the top of each quesadilla. Bake until golden brown and crispy, 8 to 10 minutes. Sprinkle with salt and let sit for a couple minutes to crisp further.

name: Ginger-Scallion Soba & Shrimp
author: ALI SLAGLE
ingredients: 4 inches ginger, peeled and coarsely chopped
2 cups snow or snap peas, trimmed and thinly sliced
1 pound large shrimp, peeled and deveined
instructions:
Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil. Peel and coarsely chop 4 inches ginger. Coarsely chop 4 scallions. Make the ginger and scallions into a little pile and top with 2 teaspoons sugar and ½ teaspoon salt. Chop and smash together into a coarse paste. Transfer to a large bowl. Stir in ¼ cup unseasoned rice vinegar, 2 tablespoons low-sodium soy sauce, and 2 tablespoons neutral oil.

Trim 2 cups snow or snap peas, then thinly slice on a very sharp diagonal so they're almost shredded. Add to the dressing bowl but don't stir. Peel and devein 1 pound large shrimp.

Add 10 ounces dried soba to the boiling water and cook according to the package directions. When your soba has 3 minutes remaining, add the shrimp and cook until pink. Drain and rinse under cold water until cool to the touch, then shake to get rid of any water. Add to the bowl of dressing and toss to coat. Taste and add more salt (or soy sauce) as needed.

name: Broccoli Bits with Cheddar & Dates
author: ALI SLAGLE
ingredients: 4 ounces (¾ cup) sharp Cheddar cheese, chopped into ¼-inch bits
½ cup smoked or roasted almonds, coarsely chopped
instructions:
Chop 4 ounces (¾ cup) sharp Cheddar cheese into ¼-inch bits and coarsely chop ½ cup smoked or roasted almonds. Transfer to a large bowl. Cut the florets off 2 pounds broccoli, keeping as much of the branch connected to the trunk as possible. Peel the trunk and cut the trunk and branches into ½-inch pieces. Roughly chop the florets into small pieces so even the biggest ones fit on a teaspoon. Pit and coarsely chop 8 dates.

In a large skillet, heat 1 tablespoon olive oil over medium-high. Add the dates and cook until they're softened and browned in spots, 2 to 3 minutes. Transfer to the bowl and season with salt and pepper.

In the same skillet still over medium-high, heat 2 tablespoons olive oil. Add the broccoli (including the specks on the cutting board) and 1 teaspoon red pepper flakes, season with salt and pepper, and cook until the broccoli is bright green and browned in spots, 3 to 5 minutes. Transfer to the bowl. Stir in 1 tablespoon Sherry vinegar, 1 tablespoon olive oil, and 1 teaspoon honey. Taste and adjust salt, acid, sweetness, and spice accordingly.

name: Chicken with So Much Garlic
author: ALI SLAGLE
ingredients: 30 fat garlic cloves (from 3 to 4 heads), smashed but not peeled
4 cups full-flavored salad greens (radicchio, frisée, arugula)
instructions:
Heat the oven to 425°F. Smash but don't peel 30 fat garlic cloves (from 3 to 4 heads). Toss on a sheet pan with enough olive oil to coat. Pat 2 pounds bone-in, skin-on chicken thighs dry. Transfer to the sheet pan and season all over with 1 teaspoon each salt and pepper and enough olive oil to coat. Arrange the chicken skin side up around the garlic, then nestle some rosemary sprigs under the chicken. Roast, without flipping, until the chicken is cooked through, 30 to 35 minutes. (Remove garlic cloves if they start to burn.)

Meanwhile, in a large bowl, combine bite-size pieces of 4 cups full-flavored salad greens. Cut 4 thick slices crusty bread.

Remove the chicken, garlic, and rosemary from the sheet pan, leaving the fat behind. Pluck some of the rosemary leaves and add back to the sheet pan. Add the bread and turn to coat in the chicken fat. Arrange the bread so the rosemary is under slices. Roast until the bread is toasted, 5 to 10 minutes.

Meanwhile, in a measuring cup, stir together the juice from 1 lemon (about 3 tablespoons) and 1 tablespoon Dijon mustard. Squeeze 10 garlic cloves into the lemon dressing. Smash with a fork, then add ½ cup olive oil, stirring to combine. Season with salt and pepper. Toss the greens with enough dressing to coat.

Eat the chicken, toasted bread, and salad with the extra garlic cloves for smushing on the bread.

name: Lemon-Pepper Chicken & Potatoes
author: ALI SLAGLE
ingredients: ½ cup chicken stock or water
3 pounds large Yukon Gold potatoes (about 6), peeled
instructions:
Heat the oven to 450°F. Zest 4 lemons into a medium bowl. Crush 2 teaspoons fennel seeds underneath a mug or skillet or in a spice grinder. Grind 1 whole tablespoon of pepper. Stir the fennel seeds and pepper into the lemon zest, along with 1 tablespoon olive oil and 1 teaspoon salt. Pat 2 pounds bone-in, skin-on chicken thighs dry, then transfer to the bowl and toss to coat.

On a sheet pan, combine ½ cup juice from the lemons, ½ cup chicken stock or water, ⅓ cup olive oil, and 1 tablespoon salt. Peel 3 pounds large Yukon Gold potatoes (about 6). Cut each potato into 8 pieces by halving crosswise, then quartering each half. Toss the potatoes in the liquid on the sheet pan, then spread into an even layer. Add the chicken skin side up on top of the potatoes, along with any seeds and oil in the bowl.

Roast until the chicken's cooked through and the potatoes are golden and tender, 60 to 65 minutes. Season to taste with salt and pepper.

name: Chicken & Rice with Smoked Paprika
author: ALI SLAGLE
ingredients: 4 scallions, thinly sliced (whites and greens separated)
instructions:
Thinly slice 4 scallions, keeping the white and green parts separate. Thinly slice 5 garlic cloves. Shred 2 to 3 cups cooked chicken.

Heat 3 tablespoons olive oil in a large nonstick skillet over medium. Add the scallion whites, the garlic, 3 tablespoons tomato paste, and 1 teaspoon smoked paprika. Season with salt and pepper and cook, stirring, until a shade darker, 3 to 4 minutes. Stir in 1 cup sushi rice until well coated.

Add 2 cups chicken stock, the chicken, and 1 teaspoon salt and bring to a boil over medium-high. Reduce the heat to low, cover with a lid, baking sheet, or foil, and cook until the rice is tender and most of the liquid is absorbed, 15 to 20 minutes.

Uncover the skillet and poke five or six holes in the rice to help steam escape. Increase the heat to medium and cook undisturbed until you start to see browned rice at the edges, 5 to 7 minutes. If you don't see oil bubbling around the edges or in the holes, drizzle in another tablespoon or two of oil.

To eat, loosen the edges and flip the rice onto a big plate, or scoop spoonfuls from the pan, making sure to get some of the crispy rice on the bottom. Top with scallion greens, salt and pepper, and a squeeze of lemon.

name: Sticky Chicken with Pickled Vegetables
author: ALI SLAGLE
ingredients: 1½ pounds boneless, skinless chicken thighs, cut into 1-inch pieces
2 inches ginger, peeled and finely grated
½ cup unseasoned rice vinegar (for pickles)
1 cup crunchy vegetables (carrot, celery, or chard stems), cut into matchsticks
instructions:
Make rice: In a medium saucepan, bring 1¼ cups water, 1 cup sushi rice, and ½ teaspoon salt to a boil. Cover, reduce the heat to the lowest setting, and cook until the rice is tender, 12 to 15 minutes. Remove from the heat and keep covered.

Meanwhile, pat 1½ pounds boneless, skinless chicken thighs dry and cut into 1-inch pieces. Toss with 1 teaspoon each salt and pepper. Peel and finely grate 2 inches ginger and 3 garlic cloves into a medium bowl. Add ½ cup low-sodium soy sauce, ⅓ cup honey, and 2 tablespoons unseasoned rice vinegar. Stir with a fork to combine. Add the chicken and stir to combine.

Make the pickles: In a measuring cup, stir together ½ cup unseasoned rice vinegar, 1 tablespoon sugar, and 2 teaspoons salt until the sugar and salt dissolve. Cut 1 cup matchsticks or thin slices crunchy vegetables. Stir into the vinegar.

Heat 1 tablespoon neutral oil in a large nonstick skillet over medium-high. Using a slotted spoon or tongs and shaking off excess glaze, add the chicken to the skillet. Cook, stirring once, until browned, 4 to 6 minutes. Add the marinade and bring to a boil. Cook, stirring the chicken in the sauce, until the sauce is dark and syrupy and the chicken is cooked through, 4 to 6 minutes. Remove from the heat and stir in 1 tablespoon butter until it's melted. Season to taste.

Back to the rice: Hold the vegetables back with your hand and pour a tablespoon or two of the pickling liquid into the rice. Stir to combine. Eat the chicken and pickled vegetables on top of a mound of seasoned rice.

name: Mighty Meatballs
author: ALI SLAGLE
ingredients: 1 cup whole-milk ricotta, plus more for toasts
5 garlic cloves (1 for meatballs, 3 for sauce, 1 for bread)
instructions:
In a medium bowl, combine 1 pound ground beef, 1 pound ground pork, 1 cup whole-milk ricotta, 2½ teaspoons salt, and ½ teaspoon pepper. Finely grate in 1 cup Parmesan (about 2 ounces) and 1 garlic clove. Rip 2 tablespoons basil leaves into the bowl; hold on to the stems. Stir with your hands to combine. Using wet hands, form into 8 balls (about ½ cup or 150 grams each).

Working in batches as needed, heat 2 tablespoons olive oil in a large Dutch oven over medium-high. Add the meatballs and cook until browned on two sides, 5 to 8 minutes. Transfer to a plate and turn off the heat.

Still off the heat, finely grate 3 garlic cloves into the pot. Add ½ teaspoon red pepper flakes. Stir until you smell the garlic, then add 2 (28-ounce) cans crushed tomatoes, 4 basil sprigs, and the reserved basil stems. Season with salt and pepper. Partially cover, bring to a simmer over medium-high, then reduce to medium-low and add the meatballs back. Add water until the sauce is halfway up the sides of the meatballs. Gently simmer partially covered, flipping the meatballs halfway through, until the sauce is flavorful and the meatballs are cooked through (160°F), 15 to 20 minutes. Season the sauce to taste.

When the meatballs are about done, slice and toast some crusty bread. Rub one side with 1 garlic clove, then smear some ricotta on each. Season with salt and pepper. Eat the meatballs in sauce with more Parm, and ricotta toasts alongside for dunking.

name: Roasted Broccolini and Lemon with Crispy Parmesan
author: ALISON ROMAN
ingredients: 2 bunches broccolini, ends trimmed, or 1½ pounds broccoli, thinly sliced lengthwise
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
½ cup finely grated Parmesan cheese
instructions:
Preheat the oven to 425°F.

Thinly slice half the lemon into rounds and set the other half aside. Toss the lemon slices, garlic, and broccolini with the olive oil on a rimmed baking sheet. Season with salt and pepper, and make sure everything is evenly coated, especially the broccolini tips so they get all fried and crispy.

Sprinkle with the Parmesan and roast until the broccolini is bright green and starting to char and the cheese is golden brown, 10 to 15 minutes.

Remove from the oven, squeeze the other half of the lemon over the top, and serve.

name: Fried Eggplant with Harissa and Dill
author: ALISON ROMAN
ingredients: Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
1 large globe eggplant, sliced into ½-inch-thick rounds
¼ cup fresh dill, tender stems and leaves, coarsely chopped
instructions:
Combine the garlic, harissa, tomato paste, cumin, vinegar, and 2 tablespoons water in a small bowl; season with salt and pepper and set aside.

Heat ½ cup olive oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat. Working in batches (all the slices will not fit at once), fry the eggplant until golden brown on both sides, 5 to 8 minutes total. Transfer the eggplant to a plate lined with paper towels to absorb any excess oil; season it with salt. Repeat with the remaining eggplant, adding more olive oil to the skillet as needed.

After the last round of eggplant is finished frying and most of the oil has been absorbed, add the harissa mixture to the skillet (it'll bubble and sizzle a bit, so stand back) and remove the skillet from the heat. Add the rest of the previously fried eggplant to the skillet and toss everything to coat in the harissa mixture. Scatter the dill over the top and serve.

name: Roasted Sweet Potatoes with Hot Honey Browned Butter
author: ALISON ROMAN
ingredients: 4 small to medium sweet potatoes, scrubbed
1 tablespoon white wine vinegar or apple cider vinegar
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
instructions:
Preheat the oven to 425°F.

Poke each sweet potato all over with a fork and place them all directly on the oven rack. Roast until they are impossibly tender, with bits of sweet potato sugar caramelizing in the spots they've been poked, 60 to 80 minutes.

Meanwhile, melt the butter in a small pot over medium heat, swirling the pot just until the butter starts to bubble and brown, about 5 minutes. Add the honey, vinegar, and red pepper flakes, and season with kosher salt and black pepper. Remove from the heat and set aside.

Once the sweet potatoes are out of the oven, slit them down the middle. Warm up the browned butter mixture and pour over the sweet potatoes. Sprinkle with tons of flaky sea salt.

name: Cumin-Roasted Cauliflower and Dates with Tahini and Pine Nuts
author: ALISON ROMAN
ingredients: 1 head of cauliflower (including any green leaves or stems), sliced lengthwise into ½-inch-thick steaks
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
6 dates, such as Medjool, pitted and halved
½ cup tender cilantro leaves and stems, coarsely chopped
2 tablespoons sherry vinegar or white wine vinegar
instructions:
Preheat the oven to 500°F.

Using your hands, break the cauliflower into smaller florets, keeping the stalks long. Toss the cauliflower and cumin with 3 tablespoons of the olive oil on a rimmed baking sheet and season with salt and pepper. Roast, tossing occasionally, until just starting to brown, 10 to 15 minutes. Add the dates, toss to coat, and continue roasting until the cauliflower is deeply browned and caramelized all over and the dates are plump and starting to caramelize around the edges, 10 to 15 minutes more.

Meanwhile, whisk the tahini and 2 tablespoons water together in a small bowl; season with salt and pepper.

Toast the pine nuts in a small skillet over medium heat, shaking the skillet occasionally, until the pine nuts are golden brown and smell like popcorn, about 5 minutes. Remove from the heat and let cool enough to coarsely chop.

In a small bowl, combine the pine nuts, scallions, mint, cilantro, vinegar, and the remaining 2 tablespoons olive oil; season with salt and pepper.

Spoon the tahini onto the bottom of a large serving platter. Remove the cauliflower and dates from the oven and place them on top of the tahini. Spoon the mint mixture over and serve.

name: Cumin Lamb Chops with Charred Scallions and Peanuts
author: ALISON ROMAN
ingredients: 1½ teaspoons kosher salt, plus more as needed
instructions:
Combine the cumin, Sichuan peppercorns, and red pepper flakes in a spice mill or mortar and pestle, and process or pound to a coarse powder (alternatively, place all the spices in a ziplock bag and crush with a rolling pin or heavy skillet). Add the salt to the spice mixture and mix well. Season the lamb chops with the cumin-salt mixture and set aside.

Heat the oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat. Sear the lamb chops until both sides are deep golden brown but the inside is still a nice pinkish rare, 3 to 4 minutes per side, depending on size. Transfer the chops to a large serving platter and let rest for 5 minutes.

Meanwhile, add the scallions to the skillet and cook, stirring occasionally, until lightly charred and all coated in the Sichuan-y, lamby fat. Add the vinegar and peanuts (if using), season with salt and black pepper, and serve alongside the lamb chops.

name: Paprika-Rubbed Sheet-Pan Chicken with Lemon
author: ALISON ROMAN
instructions:
Preheat the oven to 325°F.

Using paper towels, pat the chicken dry. Place the chicken, breast-side up, on a rimmed baking sheet.

Grind the fennel seed in a spice mill or mortar and pestle (alternatively, chop it with a knife or smash it in a ziplock bag with a heavy skillet) and place it in a bowl with the hot paprika, salt, smoked paprika, pepper, garlic, and olive oil, and smear this all over the bird. Skin side, underside, in every nook and cranny possible. Rub any of the leftover mixture onto the quartered lemons and scatter them around the chicken.

Roast the chicken until it is completely tender and cooked through and the lemons are soft and jammy, 2 to 2½ hours. Around hour 2, use a spoon or pastry brush to baste the chicken with all the garlicky business that has dripped off along with the chicken fat.

The drippings from this chicken are magnificent. Drizzle them over the chicken once it's carved, use them to crisp up smashed potatoes, drag crusty bread through them, or toss with vegetables before roasting.

name: Salted Butter and Chocolate Chunk Shortbread
author: ALISON ROMAN
ingredients: 1 cup plus 2 tablespoons (2¼ sticks) salted butter, cut into ½-inch pieces
6 ounces semi- or bittersweet dark chocolate, chopped into chunks
instructions:
Line a rimmed baking sheet with parchment paper.

Using an electric mixer, beat the butter, both sugars, and vanilla on medium-high till it's super light and fluffy, 3 to 5 minutes. Using a spatula, scrape down the sides of the bowl and, with the mixer on low, slowly add the flour, followed by the chocolate chunks, and beat just to blend.

Divide the dough in half, placing each half on a large piece of plastic wrap. Fold the plastic over so that it covers the dough. Using your hands, form the dough into a log shape; rolling it on the counter will help you smooth it out. Each half should form logs 2 to 2¼ inches in diameter. Chill until totally firm, about 2 hours.

Preheat the oven to 350°F.

Brush the outside of the logs with the beaten egg and roll them in the Demerara sugar. Slice each log into ½-inch-thick rounds, place them on the prepared baking sheet about 1 inch apart, and sprinkle with flaky salt. Bake until the edges are just beginning to brown, 12 to 15 minutes. Let cool slightly before eating.

name: Luckiest Biscuits in America
author: ALISON ROMAN
ingredients: 3 cups all-purpose flour, plus more for dusting
1 cup (2 sticks) unsalted butter, cut into 1-inch pieces, chilled
1¼ cups buttermilk, plus more for brushing
instructions:
Preheat the oven to 425°F. Line a baking sheet with parchment paper.

Whisk the flour, baking powder, kosher salt, sugar, and baking soda in a large bowl. Using your hands, smash the butter into the flour mixture. It should be almost like you're making pie dough, with little bits of butter but no large chunks.

Drizzle the buttermilk all over the dry mixture and, using a wooden spoon or your hands, mix everything until it comes together in a sort of ball. Knead the mixture a few times in the bowl, making sure to get any of those dry bits at the bottom up into the mix.

Turn the dough out onto a lightly floured work surface and knead another two or three times.

Pat the dough into a 1½-inch-thick rectangle about 12 inches long and 6 inches wide. Cut it in half lengthwise, then crosswise into 4 pieces (you should get 8 biscuits).

Place the biscuits on the parchment-lined baking sheet and brush the tops with buttermilk, letting some drip down the sides. Sprinkle the tops with flaky sea salt, if you're feeling fancy.

Bake, rotating once, until the biscuits are deeply, fantastically golden brown on the bottoms and tops, and the sides have puffed up like an accordion, 20 to 25 minutes.

name: Jen's Key Lime Pie
author: ALISON ROMAN
ingredients: 2 teaspoons finely grated lime zest, plus more for garnish
1 cup fresh lime juice (from 8 to 10 limes)
1 cup full-fat Greek yogurt or sour cream
instructions:
Make the crust: Preheat the oven to 350°F. Smash the graham crackers with your hands until you've got coarse crumbs. Mix these crumbs with the coconut oil, butter, granulated sugar, and salt until you've got really moist crumbs, almost like wet sand. Press the crumbs into a 9-inch pie plate and bake until the crust starts to lightly brown around the edges, 12 to 15 minutes. Remove from the oven and set aside to cool. Leave the oven on.

Make the filling: In a large bowl, vigorously whisk the egg yolks until they're pale and fluffy. Add the sweetened condensed milk and whisk a few more minutes, until the mixture is light and airy. Using a spatula, fold in the lime zest and lime juice. Add the salt. Pour this into your partially baked crust and return it to the oven to bake another 20 to 25 minutes. The center should barely jiggle; the top should not brown.

Remove the pie and let it cool completely, then refrigerate.

When it's time to serve, whip the heavy cream and confectioners' sugar together until they've achieved medium peaks. Whisk in the yogurt, then swirl that all over the top of the pie. Zest some lime over the top.

name: Cocoa Banana Bread
author: ALISON ROMAN
ingredients: Nonstick cooking spray, for the pan
6 tablespoons (¾ stick) unsalted butter, at room temperature
¼ cup lightly packed light brown sugar
5 extremely ripe bananas, 4 coarsely mashed and 1 sliced lengthwise
½ cup mascarpone, full-fat sour cream, or full-fat yogurt
instructions:
Preheat the oven to 350°F. Spray a 9x4-inch loaf pan with nonstick spray. Sugar the inside of the pan with ¼ cup of the Demerara sugar, tapping out any excess.

In a medium bowl, whisk the flour, cocoa powder, baking soda, and salt together; set aside.

Using an electric mixer, beat the butter, granulated sugar, light brown sugar, and vanilla on high speed until the mixture is super light and fluffy, 3 to 5 minutes. Scrape down the sides of the bowl and add the egg. Beat until well combined and the mixture returns to that previously light, fluffy state, about 2 minutes. With the mixer on low, slowly add the dry ingredients and beat just to blend. Using a spatula, fold in the mashed bananas, followed by the mascarpone, mixing just to blend.

Pour the batter into the prepared loaf pan, smoothing the top. Place the banana halves, cut-side up, on top of the batter. Sprinkle with the remaining ¼ cup Demerara sugar and bake until the sides start to pull away and the cake is baked through in the center, 90 to 100 minutes.

Let cool completely before slicing.

name: Labne with Sizzled Scallions and Chile (Almost Ranch)
author: ALISON ROMAN
ingredients: 4 scallions (or green garlic), white and light green parts, thinly sliced
2 tablespoons finely chopped fresh cilantro (tender leaves and stems) or chives, plus more for garnish
2 cups labne, full-fat Greek yogurt, or sour cream
instructions:
Heat the olive oil, scallions, crushed red pepper flakes, and cilantro in a small pot over medium-low heat. Cook, swirling occasionally, until the scallions and red pepper flakes start to visually and audibly sizzle and frizzle and turn the oil a bright fiery orange. Remove from the heat and let cool enough to taste without burning your mouth, then season with salt and pepper.

Combine the labne and lemon juice in a medium bowl and season with salt and pepper. Spoon into a bowl and swirl in the sizzled scallion mixture. Top with extra cilantro, if you like.

name: Creamy Cauliflower and Onion Gratin
author: ALISON ROMAN
ingredients: Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
2½- to 3-pound cauliflower, leafy green parts removed
½ small sweet or yellow onion, very thinly sliced
6 ounces Gruyère or white cheddar cheese, grated (about 2½ cups)
2 cups fresh coarse bread crumbs or panko (optional)
¼ cup olive oil (if using bread crumbs)
instructions:
Preheat the oven to 425°F.

Bring the cream, butter, and garlic to a simmer in a small pot over medium heat. Season with salt and pepper and remove from heat.

Slice the cauliflower into ½-inch-thick slabs (some of the bits will fall away and crumble into tiny florets; this is fine).

Layer the cauliflower and onion in a baking dish, pour the cream mixture over, and top with cheese and sesame seeds. Cover and bake until cauliflower is tender, then uncover to brown the top.

name: One-Pot Chicken with Dates and Caramelized Lemon
author: ALISON ROMAN
ingredients: 3½- to 4-pound chicken, or 3 pounds bone-in, skin-on chicken thighs or legs
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
1 lemon, cut into thick slices crosswise, seeds removed
4 sprigs fresh thyme or oregano, plus more for serving
2 teaspoons ground Urfa chile, or 1 teaspoon crushed red pepper flakes
instructions:
Preheat the oven to 425°F.

Season the chicken all over with salt and pepper. Heat 2 tablespoons of the oil in a large (at least 8-quart) Dutch oven over medium-high heat. Place the chicken in the pot breast side up, and using tongs or your hands, press lightly to make sure the skin comes into even contact with the pot bottom. This is your chance to brown the legs and render that excess fat! (If using parts, just sear the chicken skin side down.)

Cook, without moving, until the chicken is nice and browned, 5 to 8 minutes. Seriously, no peeking!

Add the lemon slices and shallot, maneuvering the chicken however you need so that the slices come into contact with the bottom of the pot. Let everything sizzle in the chicken fat until lightly caramelized, about 2 minutes.

Add the dates, thyme, and water. Sprinkle the top of the chicken with the Urfa chile and place the lid on. Put the Dutch oven in the oven and roast until the dates are plump, the lemon is jammy, and the chicken is almost but not totally cooked through, 20 to 25 minutes.

Remove the lid and drizzle the chicken with the remaining 2 tablespoons oil and continue to cook until the liquid has reduced by half and top of the chicken is an illustrious, glistening golden-brown, another 20 to 30 minutes, depending on if you're using parts or whole bird.

Let the chicken rest in the Dutch oven for 10 minutes, then transfer to a cutting board and carve. Serve along with the shallot, lemon, and dates with some more thyme and flaky sea salt sprinkled over.

name: Many Mushrooms Pot Pie
author: ALISON ROMAN
ingredients: 1½ pounds mixed mushrooms (maitake, oyster, cremini, or button), torn or cut into bite-size pieces
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
3 tablespoons fresh thyme, oregano, or marjoram leaves
2½ cups vegetable broth, chicken broth, or water
1 cup parsley, tender leaves and stems, finely chopped
instructions:
Preheat the oven to 400°F. Line a sheet pan with parchment paper.

On a lightly floured work surface, roll both discs of dough out to rounds 12-14 inches in diameter. Lay one into a 9-inch pie plate and gently drape the second round of dough over the first. Refrigerate while you prepare the filling.

In a large skillet, heat the olive oil over medium-high heat. Add half the mushrooms and season with kosher salt and pepper. Cook, stirring occasionally, until the mushrooms shrink in size and begin to brown, 5-8 minutes. Add the remaining mushrooms, season with salt and pepper, and continue to cook until all the mushrooms are about the same size and tenderness, another 8-10 minutes.

Add the garlic and onion and continue cooking until the mushrooms and onions are deeply browned, frizzled, and caramelized at the edges, another 10-15 minutes.

Reduce the heat to medium and add the butter and thyme, letting the butter melt around the mushrooms. Add the flour and stir to coat the mushrooms. Cook until the flour starts to toast in the skillet, 2-3 minutes. Slowly add the broth, stirring to combine. Add the heavy cream and simmer until the mixture is thick enough to coat the back of a spoon, about 5 minutes. Add the parsley, season with kosher salt and pepper, and remove from the heat.

Remove the pie plate from the fridge and set it on the lined sheet pan. Set the second round of dough aside. Fill the pie plate with the mushroom mixture. Lay the reserved dough round on top. Using the tines of a fork, press the top and bottom crusts together, sealing the mushroom mixture inside. Trim the excess dough.

Mix the egg with a teaspoon of water and brush the top of the crust with the egg wash. Sprinkle with flaky salt and more black pepper. Make a few incisions or slits in the top of the crust.

Bake the pie until the crust is deeply golden brown all over, on the top and underneath, 1 hour 10 minutes to 1 hour 20 minutes.

Let cool slightly before eating.

name: Cold Carrot Cake
author: ALISON ROMAN
ingredients: ½ teaspoon ground turmeric, cardamom, or ginger (optional)
⅔ cup sour cream or Greek yogurt
10-12 Medjool dates (8 ounces), pitted and chopped
¼ cup vegetable or olive oil
instructions:
Preheat the oven to 350°F. Line a 9-inch cake pan with a round of parchment paper and spray with cooking spray.

In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, cinnamon, baking soda, salt, baking powder, and turmeric (if using).

In another large bowl, whisk the eggs, brown sugar, and sour cream together until well blended. Add the carrots and dates and, using a spatula or wooden spoon, mix until all the bits are evenly dispersed. Pour the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients and use a spatula to mix until just combined. Add the melted butter along with the oil and stop mixing as soon as you've got a nice, even batter.

Pour the batter into the prepared cake pan and bake until the top is puffed and golden and the sides pull away from the pan, 40-45 minutes.

This cake can be eaten now, or, for the optimal carrot cake experience, refrigerate it until completely chilled before slicing.

For quick cream cheese frosting: combine 8 ounces softened cream cheese, ½ cup powdered sugar, and a good pinch of kosher salt together in a medium bowl. Use a fork to combine until smooth. Spread onto the cake.

name: Brown Butter Pumpkin Cake
author: ALISON ROMAN
ingredients: 2 tablespoons freshly grated ginger or 1½ teaspoons ground ginger
instructions:
Preheat the oven to 375°F. Spray one 9-inch cake pan or one 9x4-inch loaf pan with cooking spray and line with parchment paper. Or line 12 cups of a muffin tin with liners.

In a medium pot, melt the butter over medium-high heat and cook, swirling occasionally until the butter is browned, foamy, and smells like popcorn, 5-7 minutes. Remove from the heat and stir in the ginger, cinnamon, and nutmeg.

In a medium bowl, whisk together the flour, baking powder, baking soda, and salt.

In a large bowl, whisk the pumpkin puree, eggs, maple syrup, and brown sugar until combined. Slowly whisk in the flour mixture until nearly no lumps remain, followed immediately by the browned butter mixture, whisking until no lumps remain (the batter should be smooth and thick, but do not overmix).

Pour it into the prepared cake pan(s) or loaf pan, smoothing the top. Or divide among the muffin cups. Bake until golden brown on top, pulling away from the sides of the pan, and springing back lightly when pressed slightly: 25-30 minutes for cake pans, 65-75 minutes for a loaf pan, and 20-25 minutes for muffins.

Let cool entirely before frosting, if you're going to frost.

name: Cornbread
author: ALISON ROMAN
ingredients: 1 stick (4 ounces) unsalted butter, melted, plus more softened butter for serving
½ cup packed light brown sugar
¾ cup mayonnaise, sour cream, or a mix of both
instructions:
Preheat the oven to 400°F.

Spoon a bit (a tablespoon or so) of the melted butter into the bottom of a 9-inch pie plate, cake pan, or cast-iron skillet. Using a brush or your fingers, grease the dish all along the bottom and up the sides.

In a medium bowl, whisk together the flour, cornmeal, brown sugar, baking powder, salt, and pepper (if using).

In another medium bowl or measuring cup, whisk together the eggs, mayonnaise, and buttermilk.

Whisk the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients, but just until combined (a few dry spots/lumps are okay). Add the remaining melted butter to the batter and gently fold until it's totally incorporated.

Pour the batter into the prepared pan, smooth the top, and bake until the edges are deeply browned and crispy and the top is a lovely, sunflower-y golden yellow color, 20-25 minutes.

Remove from oven and let cool a few minutes before slicing. While you wait, mix some softened butter with a good amount of honey and a healthy pinch of flaky salt. Mix until shiny, glossy, and spreadable and serve with the cornbread.

name: A Better Banana Bread
author: ALISON ROMAN
ingredients: Cooking spray or softened butter and granulated sugar, for the pan
1 stick (4 ounces) butter, at room temperature
½ cup granulated sugar, plus 2-3 tablespoons
3 very ripe bananas, peeled and mashed, plus 1 banana, halved lengthwise
½ cup mascarpone, whole-milk yogurt, or sour cream
instructions:
Preheat the oven to 350°F. Line a 9x4-inch loaf pan with parchment paper. (Alternatively, spray with cooking spray or grease with softened butter and sprinkle the interior with enough granulated sugar to coat, tapping out excess—this will give you a slightly sweeter banana bread with a crunchy crust.)

In a medium bowl, whisk together the flour, baking soda, and salt.

In a stand mixer fitted with the paddle (or in a medium bowl with an electric hand mixer), cream the butter, ½ cup sugar, and the light brown sugar together until light and fluffy, 3-5 minutes. Add the eggs, one at a time. Beat until light and fluffy, another 3-5 minutes. Slowly add the flour mixture, scraping down the sides of the bowl until everything is mostly incorporated (do not overmix).

Add the mashed bananas and mascarpone and mix until well blended, making sure to get all the batter at the bottom of the bowl. Transfer the batter to the prepared loaf pan, top with the halved banana, cut-side up, and sprinkle with the remaining 2-3 tablespoons sugar.

Bake until the bread is puffed up, golden brown, and starting to pull away from the sides of the pan, 1 hour 10 minutes to 1 hour 20 minutes. (Yes, this bakes for a long time—loaf cakes, especially very moist ones, take awhile. Do not rush it or it will almost certainly collapse on you!)

Let cool completely before slicing or wrapping for later.

name: Caramelized Shallot Pasta
author: ALISON ROMAN
ingredients: 6 large shallots (about 12 ounces), very thinly sliced
5 garlic cloves (4 thinly sliced, 1 finely chopped)
1 teaspoon crushed red pepper flakes, plus more
1 (4.5-ounce) tube or (6-ounce) can tomato paste (½-¾ cup)
12-16 ounces dried pasta, preferably bucatini or spaghetti
1 cup parsley, tender leaves and stems, finely chopped
instructions:
Heat the olive oil in a large skillet or Dutch oven over medium-high heat. Add the shallots and sliced garlic and season with salt and pepper. Cook, stirring occasionally, until the shallots have become totally softened and caramelized with golden-brown fried edges, 15-20 minutes.

Add the red pepper flakes and anchovies. (No need to chop the anchovies; they will dissolve on their own.) Stir to melt the anchovies into the shallots, about 2 minutes.

Add the tomato paste and season with salt and pepper. Cook, stirring constantly to prevent any scorching, until the tomato paste has started to cook in the oil a bit, caramelizing at the edges and going from bright red to a deeper brick-red color, about 2 minutes. Remove from the heat and transfer about half of the mixture to a resealable container, leaving the rest behind for the pasta.

Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil. Cook the pasta until very al dente. Save 2 cups of pasta water, then drain the pasta. Transfer the pasta to the pot with the remaining shallot mixture and 1 cup of pasta water. Cook over medium-high heat, swirling the skillet to coat each piece of pasta, until the sauce is reduced and a little sticky, perfectly coating each strand of pasta, 3-5 minutes.

Combine the parsley and the finely chopped garlic in a small bowl and season with flaky salt and pepper. Divide the pasta among bowls and top with the parsley mixture and a few more red pepper flakes if you like.

name: Goodbye Meatballs
author: ALISON ROMAN
ingredients: 2 or 3 garlic cloves, finely grated or chopped
½ medium yellow or red onion, very finely chopped
Freshly ground black pepper and/or crushed red pepper flakes
1½ medium yellow or red onions, finely chopped (for sauce)
A few anchovies or couple of dashes of fish sauce (optional)
2 (28-ounce) cans crushed tomatoes and/or whole peeled tomatoes
instructions:
Make the meatballs: Mix the ricotta, parsley, Parmesan, breadcrumbs, eggs, garlic, and onion in a medium bowl. Season with salt, pepper, and red pepper flakes (if you like), and let sit for 10 minutes or so. This hydrates the breadcrumbs, which leads to very juicy meatballs.

Add the beef, pork, and remaining 2 teaspoons kosher salt. Using your hands, mix everything together well—it should look like sausage, evenly flecked with bits here and there, but not paste-like. Once it is well mixed, roll one tiny sacrificial meatball to cook.

Heat the olive oil in a large pot over medium heat. Add the sacrificial meatball and cook until it's well browned on all sides and cooked through. Eat it and adjust the seasoning as needed.

Roll the rest of the mixture into balls 1½-2 inches in diameter. Working in batches, brown the meatballs on all sides, 4-6 minutes per batch. They will not be cooked through—they will finish cooking in the sauce. Transfer browned meatballs to a plate.

Make the sauce: Without wiping out the pot, add the onions and garlic and season with salt and pepper. Cook, stirring occasionally, until translucent and tender, 8-10 minutes. Add the tomato paste and anchovies (if using) and stir until the anchovies are melted and the tomato paste has caramelized, 2-3 minutes.

Add the canned tomatoes. Fill one empty can halfway with water, swirl to get all the tomato bits out, and pour into the pot. Season with salt and pepper.

Bring to a simmer and add your meatballs and all the juices collected on the plate. Reduce the heat to low and simmer uncovered until the sauce is thickened and the meatballs are cooked through and tender, 30-40 minutes.

name: Spiced Squash & Lentil Soup with Fried Shallots
author: ALISON ROMAN
ingredients: 2 tablespoons unsalted butter (or more olive oil)
3 large shallots or 1 large red onion, thinly sliced
1 teaspoon cumin seed, or ¾ teaspoon ground cumin
½ teaspoon crushed red pepper flakes, plus more
1 small acorn, kabocha, or butternut squash (1¾-2 pounds), peeled, seeded, cut into 1-inch pieces
2 teaspoons sherry vinegar or white wine vinegar, plus more
2 cups coarsely chopped mixed herbs (cilantro, dill, chives, and/or scallions)
Yogurt or sour cream, for serving
instructions:
Heat the butter and olive oil in a large pot over medium heat. Add the shallots and season with salt and pepper. Cook, stirring occasionally, until the shallots are starting to turn a nice golden-brown, 10-12 minutes.

Add the cumin and red pepper flakes. Stir, cooking for a minute or two to bloom the spices a bit in the fat. Using a fork or slotted spoon, remove about half of the shallots and set aside.

Add the squash and garlic to the pot and season with salt and pepper. Cook, stirring every now and then, until the garlic is tender and the squash starts to fall apart (it should look like a very coarse mash), 15-20 minutes.

Add the lentils and water or broth and season with salt and pepper. Bring to a gentle simmer, letting the squash melt into the broth as the lentils become tender and follow suit, 30-35 minutes. Things should be getting to split-pea-soup texture—not entirely smooth but creamy with bits of squash here and there.

To serve, season the soup with the vinegar and more salt and pepper, if needed. Ladle soup into each bowl, and top with the herbs, stirring to let them wilt into the soup a little. Spoon yogurt or sour cream into the soup, then top with the reserved shallots, a drizzle of olive oil, and maybe another grind of pepper or a pinch of red pepper flakes.

name: Buttered Tomato Soup with Lentils & Fennel
author: ALISON ROMAN
ingredients: 2 tablespoons unsalted butter (or more olive oil)
1 medium yellow or red onion or 2 large shallots, thinly sliced
½ teaspoon crushed red pepper flakes, plus more
1 (28-ounce) can whole peeled tomatoes, crushed by hand
6 cups water, vegetable broth, or chicken broth
Sour cream, full-fat yogurt, or Parmesan cheese (optional)
instructions:
Heat the butter and 2 tablespoons olive oil in a large pot over medium-high heat. Add the garlic, fennel, and onion. Season with salt and pepper and cook, stirring occasionally, until the fennel and onions are completely softened and start to caramelize a bit, 12-15 minutes.

Add the fennel seed and red pepper flakes, stirring to encourage contact with the pot so the spices have a chance to toast for a minute or two. Add the lentils, crushed tomatoes, and 6 cups of liquid of your choosing.

Season everything with salt and pepper and bring to a strong simmer. Reduce the heat to medium-low and continue to cook until the lentils have nearly disappeared into the pot, 45-50 minutes. Stir every now and then to encourage the lentils and tomatoes to break down.

To serve, give the soup one more season with salt and pepper. Ladle the soup into bowls and finish with more olive oil, pepper, and red pepper flakes. Spoon a little dollop of sour cream or yogurt into the bottom of your bowl if desired.

name: A Chili, Because You Asked
author: ALISON ROMAN
ingredients: 3-4 pounds chuck roast, sirloin, or brisket, cut into 1½-inch pieces
2 tablespoons neutral oil or olive oil
¾ cup tomato paste (from one 6-ounce can)
2 tablespoons cumin seed or 1 tablespoon ground cumin
1½ teaspoons crushed red pepper flakes, plus more
2 (12-ounce) cans beer (something light, like a lager) or 3 cups water
1 pound dried beans (white, black, or pinto, or use a mix)
Toppings: thinly sliced scallions, fresh or pickled red onion, shredded cheddar cheese, sour cream, chopped cilantro, sliced jalapeños, crumbled Fritos, lime wedges
instructions:
Season the beef with salt and pepper. Heat the oil in a large heavy-bottomed pot over medium-high heat. Add the beef in one layer and cook until deeply browned on all sides, 15-18 minutes total. Transfer the beef to a large plate or bowl, leaving the fat behind; set aside.

Add the onions and garlic to the pot, season with salt and pepper, and cook, stirring occasionally, until they're softened, 3-5 minutes. Add the tomato paste and cook until it caramelizes a bit on the bottom of the pot, 2-3 minutes. Add the cumin, smoked paprika, hot paprika, and red pepper flakes and cook, stirring constantly for a minute or so to toast.

Add the beer and use a wooden spoon to scrape up the caramelized bits on the bottom of the pot. Add the tomatoes, beans, 8 cups water, and the beef plus any juices. Season with salt and pepper and bring to a strong simmer.

Reduce the heat to medium-low—you want a gentle simmer—and cover the pot about 90 percent of the way. Cook, checking and stirring only occasionally, until the pot has thickened into a beautiful chili and the beef and beans are completely tender and nearly falling apart, 3-3½ hours.

Remove from the heat and, using a wooden spoon, encourage the hunks of beef to break down into smaller shreddy bits by gently pressing them against the side of the pot. Stir so the meat is evenly distributed and season once more with salt, pepper, and maybe red pepper flakes.

Serve with all the toppings.

name: Toasted Rice Pilaf with Crushed Walnuts & Dates
author: ALISON ROMAN
ingredients: ¾ cup walnuts, crushed or finely chopped
1 garlic clove, finely chopped or grated
4-6 dates, preferably Medjool, pitted and chopped
1 cup basmati, jasmine, or Jasmati rice
2 large shallots or 1 medium onion, finely chopped
1 lemon, thinly sliced, seeded, or ½ preserved lemon, finely chopped
1¼ cups chicken or vegetable broth, or water
instructions:
Heat 2 tablespoons of the olive oil in a medium pot over medium heat. Add the walnuts, season with salt and pepper, and cook, stirring often, until well toasted, about 4 minutes. Transfer the walnuts (and oil) to a small bowl and add the garlic, dates, and an additional 2 tablespoons of the olive oil. Season with salt and pepper and set aside. Wipe out any walnut bits from the pot.

Rinse the rice very well in cold water, changing the water each time until it runs clear; set aside.

Heat the butter and the remaining 2 tablespoons olive oil in that same pot over medium-high heat. Add the shallots and season with salt and pepper. Cook, stirring occasionally, until nicely tender but without too much color, 8-10 minutes.

Add the lemon, rice, and turmeric (if using), stirring constantly to toast the rice in the butter mixture, until the grains have turned a light golden-brown color, 5-8 minutes. Add the broth, season with salt and pepper, and bring to a simmer. Reduce the heat to low, cover the pot, and let cook until all the liquid has evaporated and the rice is fluffy and tender, 15-18 minutes.

Remove from the heat, fluff with a fork or spoon, and spoon the garlicky date mixture over the top, giving it a good (but gentle) toss to incorporate. Cover to rest another 5-10 minutes before serving.

name: Sungold Tomato and Cherry Salad with Baked Feta and Little Gem Lettuce
author: AMANDA FREDERICKSON
instructions:
Preheat the oven to 400°F.

Place the block of feta in a small ovenproof dish. Drizzle with the olive oil. Roast the feta for 8 minutes, or until soft. Carefully drizzle with the honey and continue baking for 1 minute more, or until the top of the feta is light golden brown.

In a large bowl, combine the Sungold tomatoes and the pitted and halved cherries. Tear and add the Little Gem lettuce.

Carefully drain the oil from the feta. Mix with the red wine vinegar and drizzle over the salad. Serve the salad topped with chunks of the warm feta. Taste for salt and pepper and serve immediately.

name: Herby Turkey Meatball Pitas
author: AMANDA FREDERICKSON
instructions:
Preheat the oven to 425°F. Place a large cast-iron skillet or roasting pan in the oven while it preheats.

Warm 2 tablespoons of olive oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat. Add the thinly sliced onion and a pinch of salt and sauté until soft, 4 to 6 minutes. Add the garlic, cumin, coriander, and red pepper flakes and cook, stirring, until fragrant, 60 seconds. Let cool slightly in a large bowl.

Pulse the parsley and mint in a food processor, add the onion mixture, and pulse until smooth; return to the bowl. Add the ground turkey, bread crumbs, a pinch of salt, and a pinch of black pepper. Divide the mixture into 2-inch round meatballs.

Carefully remove the pan from the oven and pour in 2 tablespoons of olive oil. Add the meatballs in a single layer and roast for 18 to 20 minutes, turning over after 8 minutes, until they reach 165°F on a meat thermometer.

Serve the warm meatballs with a dollop of cucumber yogurt sauce, a warm pita, and pickled onions.

name: One-Pot Chicken with Orzo and Sun-Dried Tomatoes
author: AMANDA FREDERICKSON
ingredients: ½ cup coarsely chopped sun-dried tomatoes
instructions:
Preheat the oven to 375°F.

Sprinkle the chicken thighs with a large pinch of salt. In a large skillet or Dutch oven, warm the olive oil over medium heat. Add the chicken, skin-side down, and brown for 4 to 6 minutes, working in batches as needed. Remove the chicken, carefully draining all but 2 tablespoons of the fat, add the diced onion, and sauté for 4 to 6 minutes, until the onion is soft and translucent. Add the minced garlic and a pinch of cracked black pepper; continue to cook for 30 seconds.

Add the orzo and sun-dried tomatoes and sauté for another 30 seconds. Deglaze with the white wine and cook until the liquid is reduced by half. Add the chicken stock and thinly sliced lemon. Return the chicken to the pan skin-side up and place the uncovered skillet in the oven. Roast for 35 to 40 minutes, until the chicken is cooked through and the orzo has absorbed the liquid.

Let the chicken sit for 5 minutes before serving.

name: Skirt Steak Fajitas
author: AMANDA FREDERICKSON
ingredients: ¼ cup neutral oil, plus more for cooking
instructions:
In a medium bowl, combine the soy sauce, lime juice and zest, neutral oil, brown sugar, cumin, garlic, and chili powder. Mix well and set aside 2 tablespoons. Add the skirt steak (cut in half if long), cover the bowl, and refrigerate for at least an hour, or up to 12 hours.

Warm 2 tablespoons of neutral oil in a large cast iron skillet over medium heat. Add the sliced onion, sliced red bell pepper, and the reserved marinade and sauté for 4 to 6 minutes, until soft. Transfer to a plate.

In the same cast-iron pan, warm 2 tablespoons of neutral oil, if needed, over medium heat. Remove the steak from the marinade, place it in the skillet, and cook for 6 to 8 minutes for medium rare, flipping halfway through. Transfer the steak to a clean plate and allow to rest.

Thinly slice the steak against the grain. Serve the fajitas with warmed flour tortillas, the onion and red bell pepper mixture, avocado slices, sour cream, and fresh salsa.

name: Zucchini Banana Muffins
author: AMANDA FREDERICKSON
ingredients: ½ cup packed light brown sugar
2 cups shredded zucchini, water gently squeezed out
instructions:
Preheat the oven to 350°F. Line a 12-cup muffin pan with paper liners and spray lightly with nonstick cooking spray.

In a small bowl, whisk to combine the flour, cinnamon, baking soda, baking powder, and salt. Set aside.

In the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat together the mashed banana, melted coconut oil, brown sugar, and vanilla extract. With the mixer on low, slowly add the eggs, one at a time, followed by the shredded zucchini.

Add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients and mix until just barely combined. Spoon into prepared muffin pan. Bake for 22 to 25 minutes, until a toothpick inserted into a muffin comes out clean.

Let cool slightly before serving. Store at room temperature in an airtight container for up to 3 days or freeze in a plastic bag up to a month.

name: Sweet & Spicy Hot Chile Chicken Noodles
author: AMBITIOUS KITCHEN
ingredients: 1 pound 93% lean ground chicken (or ground turkey)
3 tablespoons sambal oelek (or another hot chili paste)
2 tablespoons julienned fresh Thai basil (or regular basil)
2 tablespoons rice vinegar or black vinegar
10 ounces long noodles (fettuccine, pappardelle, or 6 ounces ramen/rice noodles)
Chopped roasted cashews or peanuts, for topping
instructions:
Cook the chicken: In a large pot, warm the sesame oil over medium-high heat. Once the oil is hot, add the chicken, salt, and a few grinds of pepper. Use a wooden spoon to break up the chicken and cook, stirring occasionally, until nice and golden, about 5 minutes. Stir in the garlic, ginger, and coconut sugar and continue to cook the meat, breaking it up into smaller chunks, until it's cooked through, 2 to 3 minutes.

Add the sambal oelek and tomato paste. Sauté, stirring to fully incorporate the pastes with the meat mixture, until the chili paste is toasted and fragrant, 30 seconds to 1 minute. Once combined, add the broth, soy sauce, basil, and rice vinegar. Bring to a simmer, then reduce the heat to low and cook, uncovered and stirring every so often, until the sauce begins to thicken, 20 to 25 minutes. Remove from the heat.

Cook the noodles: While the sauce cooks, bring a large pot of generously salted water to a boil over high heat. Add the noodles and cook according to the package directions until al dente. Before draining, reserve 1 cup of the pasta water, then drain the pasta and add the cooked noodles to the pot with the meat sauce. Using tongs, toss the noodles with the chicken mixture, adding in the pasta water a few tablespoons at a time until your sauce is glossy and the noodles are well coated.

Divide the noodles into bowls and serve warm, topped with lots of basil, cashews, and red pepper flakes (if using).

name: Change Your Life Brown Butter Chocolate Chip Cookies
author: AMBITIOUS KITCHEN
ingredients: 1½ cups (320 grams) packed dark brown sugar
1 large egg plus 1 large egg yolk, at room temperature
¾ cup (135 grams) semisweet chocolate chips
¾ cup (135 grams) milk or dark chocolate chips or chunks
instructions:
Line a large plate or baking sheet with parchment paper.

Brown the butter: Melt the butter in a small saucepan over medium heat. Once melted, whisk constantly; the butter will begin to crackle, then foam. After a few minutes, the butter will begin to turn a golden amber color. As soon as the butter turns brown and gives off a nutty aroma, 5 to 8 minutes, remove from the heat and immediately transfer it to a medium bowl, scraping all the butter and brown bits from the pan. Set aside until cool enough to touch, about 15 minutes.

Mix the wet ingredients: In the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with the paddle attachment, mix the brown butter, brown sugar, and granulated sugar until well combined, about 1 minute. Beat in the egg, egg yolk, vanilla, and yogurt until the mixture is smooth and creamy, about 1 minute.

Prepare the dry ingredients: In another large bowl, whisk the flour, baking soda, and salt until well combined. With the mixer running on low speed, slowly add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients and mix just until combined, about 1 minute. Add both types of chocolate chips and mix on low speed until just incorporated into the dough. Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and place in the fridge for 10 minutes.

Chill the dough: Use a medium cookie scoop to measure 2 heaping tablespoons of the dough, roll into balls, and place onto the prepared plate. Cover with plastic wrap and refrigerate for a minimum of 2 hours and a maximum of 24 hours.

When ready to bake, preheat oven to 350°F. Line a large baking sheet with parchment paper. Remove the dough from the fridge to soften for 15 minutes.

Bake the cookies: Transfer the dough balls to the prepared baking sheet, placing them 2 inches apart. Bake until the edges just begin to turn golden brown, 9 to 11 minutes. Cool on the sheet for 5 minutes, then sprinkle each cookie with flaky sea salt. Transfer to a wire rack to cool completely.

name: Chicken Couscous with Crushed Pistachio Olive Dressing & Feta
author: AMBITIOUS KITCHEN
ingredients: 3 garlic cloves, minced (plus 3 more for couscous)
1½ pounds bone-in, skin-on chicken thighs (about 4 large)
3 medium carrots, cut diagonally into ¼-inch slices
Crushed pistachios and olives for dressing
instructions:
Marinate the chicken: In a large bowl, whisk 2 tablespoons of the olive oil, the lemon zest and juice, brine, garlic, paprika, dried oregano, salt, and a few grinds of pepper until combined. Add the chicken and turn over to coat. Cover with plastic wrap and marinate for 30 minutes at room temperature or up to 2 hours in the fridge. Before cooking, bring to room temperature for 20 to 30 minutes.

Position a rack in the middle of the oven and preheat to 425°F.

Brown the chicken: In a deep, large, oven-safe skillet or Dutch oven, warm the remaining 2 tablespoons of olive oil over medium-high heat. Remove the chicken from the marinade, allowing any excess to drip off. Once the oil is hot, carefully place the chicken skin-side down into the pan and cook, undisturbed, until the skin is golden brown, 4 to 5 minutes. Turn the chicken over and cook until browned on the other side, 4 to 5 minutes. Transfer the chicken to a plate.

Make the couscous: Return the skillet to the stove and place over medium heat. Add the carrots, lemon slices, and shallot and cook, stirring occasionally, until the shallots are tender, 3 to 5 minutes. Remove the lemons and transfer to the plate with the chicken. Stir in the couscous and garlic and cook, stirring frequently, until the couscous is golden and toasted, 1 to 2 minutes. Immediately add the broth, salt, and pepper, stirring to combine. Bring to a simmer and add the chicken skin-side up on top of the couscous, then nestle in the lemon slices.

Bake the chicken and couscous: Transfer the skillet to the oven and bake on the middle rack until the chicken is fully cooked and reads 165°F on a meat thermometer, about 20 minutes.

Top with crushed pistachio olive dressing, feta, parsley, a drizzle of honey, and flaky sea salt and pepper. Serve immediately.

name: Crispy Cornflake Chicken Tenders
author: AMBITIOUS KITCHEN
ingredients: ½ teaspoon freshly ground black pepper
Hot honey or honey mustard sauce, for serving
instructions:
Preheat the oven to 400°F. Place an oven-safe metal wire rack on a large baking sheet. Spray the rack with cooking spray.

Make the cornflake coating: In a food processor, pulse the cornflakes until they resemble fine bread crumbs. Transfer to a medium bowl and whisk in the paprika, onion powder, garlic powder, salt, and pepper until well combined.

Prepare the chicken: In another medium bowl, whisk the eggs and milk until well combined. Dip a chicken tender into the egg mixture, coating both sides. Use tongs to grab it and transfer to the cornflake mixture. Toss to completely coat both sides, then use tongs to transfer the chicken to the prepared wire rack on the baking sheet. Repeat with remaining chicken tenders.

Cook the chicken: Generously spray the tops of the chicken tenders with cooking spray. Bake until golden brown on the outside and a meat thermometer inserted into the thickest part of the tender reads 165°F, 15 to 20 minutes.

Transfer to a serving platter, drizzle with hot honey or serve honey mustard sauce on the side for dipping. Serve immediately.

name: Everyone's Favorite Baked Chicken Tacos
author: AMBITIOUS KITCHEN
ingredients: 1 tablespoon extra-virgin olive oil, plus ¼ cup for brushing
1 small orange bell pepper, very finely diced
1 pound 93% lean ground chicken (or ground turkey)
¾ cup salsa of your choice
5 ounces shredded Monterey Jack cheese (1¼ cups)
4 ounces shredded pepper Jack cheese (1 cup)
Spicy cilantro yogurt sauce, for serving
instructions:
Preheat the oven to 425°F. Line two large baking sheets with parchment paper.

Make the filling: In a large, deep skillet, warm the olive oil over medium heat. Once the oil is hot, add the onion, bell pepper, zucchini, and corn, and sauté, stirring occasionally, until softened, 5 to 8 minutes. Move the veggies to the edges of the pan.

Add the chicken to the middle of the pan, breaking apart the meat with a wooden spoon, and cook, stirring frequently, until no longer pink, about 5 minutes. Stir in the adobo, cumin, paprika, chili powder, garlic powder, salt, and pepper. Cook, stirring frequently, until the spices are toasted and fragrant, about 1 minute. Stir in the salsa and cilantro and cook until the excess liquid cooks off, 5 minutes. Remove from the heat.

Make the tacos: Wrap 4 tortillas in a damp paper towel and microwave for 30 to 45 seconds to make the tortillas pliable. Lightly brush each tortilla with about 1 teaspoon of olive oil and place oil-side down on the prepared baking sheets. Mix together the cheeses. Add 1 tablespoon of the cheese mixture to one side of the tortilla, then top with ¼ cup of the filling, 2 pickled jalapeño slices (if using), and another 1 tablespoon of cheese. Fold the tortilla over to make a taco. Repeat with remaining tortillas.

Bake the tacos: Bake for 4 minutes, then check to see if any tortillas have popped open. If so, press down with a spatula. Bake for another 5 minutes, then flip the tacos and rotate the pans. Bake until crispy and golden brown, 6 to 8 minutes. Allow to cool 5 to 10 minutes before serving with spicy cilantro yogurt sauce.

name: Hot Chile Basil Lime Chicken Burgers with Bangin' Sauce
author: AMBITIOUS KITCHEN
ingredients: 1 pound 93% lean ground chicken (or ground turkey)
Avocado oil, for grilling or frying
instructions:
If grilling, preheat the grill to medium-high heat (about 400°F). Line a baking sheet with parchment paper.

Make the burgers: In a large bowl, combine the chicken, panko, garlic, scallions, basil, cilantro, sambal oelek, brown sugar, mayo, soy sauce, ginger, lime zest, salt, and pepper. Mix with clean hands just until evenly combined. If time allows, cover and rest in the fridge for 30 minutes.

Divide the meat mixture into 4 equal portions. Using slightly damp hands, shape into ¾-inch-thick patties and place on the prepared baking sheet.

Cook the burgers: To grill, brush the grates with avocado oil. Transfer patties to the hot grill and cook until a meat thermometer reads 165°F, 4 to 5 minutes per side. To pan-fry, warm about 1 tablespoon of avocado oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat. Sear until golden brown and cooked through, 4 to 5 minutes per side.

Toast the buns: Spread the butter over the cut side of the bun halves, place face-down and cook until toasted, about 1 minute.

Assemble the burgers: Add 1 heaping tablespoon bangin' sauce to each half of the toasted buns. Top each bottom bun with lettuce, then add the burger patty, about ¼ cup of slaw, and avocado slices. Top with the remaining bun and serve immediately.

name: Crispy, Sticky Orange Tofu Stir-Fry
author: AMBITIOUS KITCHEN
ingredients: 3 tablespoons avocado oil, divided, plus more as needed
¾ cup fresh orange juice (from 2 to 3 oranges)
1 large red bell pepper, thinly sliced
8 ounces fresh green beans, ends trimmed
instructions:
Prepare the tofu: Wrap the tofu in two layers of paper towels and set on a plate. Place a heavy skillet or pot on top and let sit for 15 to 20 minutes to squeeze out the excess liquid.

Meanwhile, make the orange sauce: In a medium bowl, whisk the orange zest, orange juice, soy sauce, honey, rice vinegar, ginger, cornstarch, garlic, and red pepper flakes until well combined. Set aside.

Unwrap the tofu, discard the paper towels, and cut into 1-inch cubes. Transfer the tofu to a medium bowl and sprinkle with the cornstarch and salt. Gently toss until well coated.

Cook the tofu: Line a large plate with paper towels. In a large nonstick skillet, warm 2 tablespoons avocado oil over medium-high heat. Once hot, add the tofu in a single layer, working in batches if necessary, and cook until brown and crispy, 2 to 3 minutes per side. Transfer to the prepared plate.

Cook the stir-fry: In the same skillet, warm 1 tablespoon oil over medium heat. Add the onion, carrot, red bell pepper, green beans, and cashews. Cook, stirring frequently, until the green beans are slightly tender but still have a bite, 6 to 8 minutes. Stir in the cooked tofu. Pour in the orange sauce, bring to a gentle simmer, then reduce the heat to low and cook, stirring frequently, until the sauce begins to thicken, 2 to 4 minutes.

Top with the scallions and sesame seeds and serve immediately with coconut rice on the side.

name: Creamy Baked Butternut Squash Mac & Cheese with Sage-Walnut Bread Crumbs
author: AMBITIOUS KITCHEN
ingredients: 1 tablespoon extra-virgin olive oil, plus more for greasing
2 to 3 cups cubed butternut squash (½-inch pieces)
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
½ cup whole milk (for squash puree)
3 ounces shredded sharp Cheddar cheese (¾ cup)
instructions:
Preheat the oven to 375°F. Line a large baking sheet with parchment paper. Grease a 9-inch square pan with olive oil and set aside.

Roast the butternut squash: Place the butternut squash on the prepared baking sheet, drizzle with the oil, season with salt and pepper, and toss together. Spread out in a single layer and roast undisturbed until the squash is fork-tender, 25 to 30 minutes. (Leave the oven on.)

Cook the pasta: Meanwhile, bring a large pot of generously salted water to a boil. Cook the pasta according to package directions until al dente. Drain and set aside.

When the squash is done roasting, add the cubes to a blender along with ½ cup milk. Blend until completely smooth, about 1 minute.

Make the sauce: In another large pot, melt the butter over medium heat, then whisk in the flour, cooking and whisking constantly until a paste forms, about 30 seconds. Slowly stream in the 2 cups milk, constantly whisking away any lumps, until smooth. Raise the heat to medium-high, bring to a rapid simmer, then reduce to medium-low and simmer until the sauce thickens to the consistency of gravy, 3 to 5 minutes. Reduce the heat to low and stir in the salt, garlic powder, onion powder, paprika, red pepper flakes, a pinch of nutmeg, and lots of pepper. Fold in the Cheddar, Gruyère, and Parmesan cheeses and stir until completely melted. Stir in the squash purée until well combined and smooth.

Add the pasta to the sauce and stir well, then pour the mixture into the prepared baking dish and spread into an even layer.
